awd_titl_txt: Heterogeneous agent modeling of the personal data economy
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2). This award was provided as part of NSF's Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships (SPRF) program. The goal of the SPRF program is to prepare promising, early career doctoral-level scientists for scientific careers in academia, industry or private sector, and government. SPRF awards involve two years of training under the sponsorship of established scientists and encourage Postdoctoral Fellows to perform independent research. NSF seeks to promote the participation of scientists from all segments of the scientific community, including those from underrepresented groups, in its research programs and activities; the postdoctoral period is considered to be an important level of professional development in attaining this goal. Each Postdoctoral Fellow must address important scientific questions that advance their respective disciplinary fields. Under the sponsorship of Dr. Katherine Strandburg at New York University School of Law, this postdoctoral fellowship award supports an early career scientist investigating heterogeneous agent modeling of the personal data economy. Digital platforms have come to mediate every aspect of social and economic life. The economy of personal data collected by these services intersects the financial system through credit scoring institutions and the valuations of companies. It also intersects the real economy through its role in marketing. Data’s value and impact come in part from how it mediates and connects heterogeneous actors. The proper regulation of this data economy is an urgent political matter. This research addresses the fundamental scientific question of the macroeconomic properties of personal data as it flows between social contexts, sectors, and platforms. The work will contribute to both a general economic theory of privacy as well as methods in computational economics and finance. New modeling techniques that address personal data’s hybrid role as strategic position and tradable asset will be disseminated in open source software research toolkits. Salient results will be presented to federal agencies to advise regulation of the digital economy.

This research applies and extends heterogeneous agent modeling (HAM) methods used in macroeconomics and financial research. Heterogeneous agent modeling (HAM) includes both rational agent stochastic dynamic programming (SDP) and zero-intelligence agent based models (ABM). The data economy case motivates fundamental research about how to synthesize SDP and ABM into a framework that supports endogenous information flows. Heterogeneous actors in the economy of personal data are marked by different levels of bounded rationality, including the ability to foresee consequences of intertemporal choice. Their interactions may also result in unknown or uninvestigated emergent properties. Through the investigation of particular aspects of the data economy, such as its intersections with the credit system, product development, and data intermediary governance, this work will develop modeling tools that combine HAM with insights from Pearlian causality theory, Partially Observable Markov Decision Processes, and the institutional economics of Ostrom and Williamson.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This fellowship supported the work of Dr. Sebastian Benthall in his early career. His work addressed fundamental scientific questions raised by the design of data protection, privacy, and AI regulations. The value and consequences of personal data and artificial intelligence arise through the strategic interaction of heterogeneous agents in the economy. Prior to this research, there had been little work adapting heterogeneous agent modeling techniques to these policy challenges. Dr. Benthall produced refined analysis of platform and AI regulation through the lenses of financial and fiduciary law. He also architected new computational economics tools for designing and solving agent-based models, heterogeneous agent models, and hybrid models combining both techniques. Lastly, he developed new formal methods for modeling data protection scenarios using multi-agent influence diagrams, expanding these tools to the design of privacy enhancing technologies and adaptive regulation.

 

Policy analysis


The rise of omnibus data protection laws in Europe and elsewhere has raised questions about the shape of technology policy in the U.S. In original policy analysis funded by this award, Dr. Benthall analyzed how the data economy intersects the financial system, suggesting that the tools and powers of macroprudential financial regulation can complement privacy rules based on consumer protection. Building on this line of inquiry, Dr. Benthall performed pioneering analysis of how fiduciary duties can be adapted to artificially intelligent systems that operate with personal data. These analyses have raised many new research questions, which can be promisingly addressed using agent based, heterogeneous agent, and multi agent influence diagram techniques.

 

Computational tools


Dr. Benthall led the engineering of a large-scale simulation study of the interaction between consumer households, modeled using a heterogeneous agent modeling framework, and an agent-based model of the financial system. This system, SHARKFin, has been used to study macroprudential stability under conditions of adaptive and heterogeneous expectations, as well as the implications of best execution rules for broker-dealers The latter is a prominent example of a fiduciary duty applied to the platform economy.


Dr. Benthall has also developed new open source tools for heterogenous and agent-based modeling. As contributions to the Econ-ARK open source software project, Dr. Benthall has architected general tools and techniques for heterogeneous agent modeling with complex lifecycle problem structures.

 

Appropriate Information Flow


This fellowship has supported fundamental scientific research into the nature of privacy. This work involves a novel formalization of Helen Nissenbaum?s theory of Contextual Integrity in terms of causal game theory. In this framing, information flows are represented as edges in a multi-agent causal influence diagram. Dr. Benthall has investigated how, by augmenting the original causal influence diagram formalism with new kinds of edges, it is possible to represent problems concerning the design and implementation of privacy enhancing technologies. For example, this framework can be used to tune the parameters of a differentially private system. It also can serve as the foundation for a system of adaptive regulation of privacy. The fellowship supported the early stages of this work, including several workshop presentations.
